lessons.title: Introduction to Cells
lessons.description: This lesson will introduce you to the basic building blocks of all living things: cells.

pages.title: What is a Cell?
pages.description: Cells are the fundamental unit of life. They are microscopic units that contain all the instructions needed for an organism to live and grow.

textContent.htmlText:
All living things, from the simplest bacteria to the most complex animals, are made up of cells. Cells are often called the building blocks of life. Just like bricks can be used to build a house, cells can be used to build an organism.

Cells are very small. Most cells can only be seen with a microscope. There are many different shapes and sizes of cells, but they all have some basic things in common.

pages.title: The Parts of a Cell
pages.description: Cells have many different parts, each with a specific function.

textContent.htmlText:
The main parts of a cell are:

  • Cell membrane: The cell membrane controls what goes in and out of the cell.
  • Cytoplasm: The cytoplasm is the jelly-like substance that fills the cell and holds all the other parts of the cell in place.
  • Nucleus: The nucleus is the control center of the cell. It contains the cell's DNA, which is the genetic material that tells the cell how to make proteins.
  • Ribosomes: Ribosomes are tiny machines that make proteins according to the instructions from the DNA.

There are many other parts of a cell, but these are the main ones.

lessons.title: The Cell Cycle
lessons.description: This lesson will explore the different stages of the cell cycle, the process by which cells grow and divide.

pages.title: What is the Cell Cycle?
pages.description: The cell cycle is a series of events that take place in a cell leading to its division and duplication (replication).

textContent.htmlText:
The cell cycle is a fundamental process in all living organisms. It ensures that new cells are produced to replace old or damaged cells, and to allow for growth and development.

The cell cycle is divided into two main phases: interphase and mitosis.

pages.title: Interphase
pages.description: Interphase is the longest phase of the cell cycle, and it is divided into three stages: G1, S, and G2.

textContent.htmlText: During G1 phase, the cell grows and prepares for DNA replication. In S phase, the cell's DNA is replicated. During G2 phase, the cell continues to grow and prepares for mitosis.

pages.title: Mitosis
pages.description: Mitosis is the process of cell division, and it is divided into four stages: prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase.

textContent.htmlText: During prophase, the chromosomes condense and become visible. During metaphase, the chromosomes line up in the middle of the cell. During anaphase, the chromosomes are pulled apart to opposite ends of the cell. During telophase, two new nuclei form around the chromosomes.

pages.title: Task: Cell Cycle Stages
pages.description: Test your knowledge about the different stages of the cell cycle.

lessons.title: Photosynthesis
lessons.description: This lesson will explore the process of photosynthesis, how plants use sunlight to convert water and carbon dioxide into food.

pages.title: What is Photosynthesis?
pages.description: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight to convert water and carbon dioxide into glucose, a type of sugar that plants use for food.

textContent.htmlText:
Photosynthesis is essential for life on Earth. It provides the oxygen that we breathe and the food that we eat.

Photosynthesis takes place in the chloroplasts of plant cells. Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll, a green pigment that absorbs sunlight.

pages.title: The Process of Photosynthesis
pages.description: Photosynthesis is a complex process that involves many steps.

textContent.htmlText: The first step in photosynthesis is the absorption of sunlight by chlorophyll. The energy from sunlight is used to split water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen. The hydrogen is then used to convert carbon dioxide into glucose.
